Item 1. Business.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART I - Item 1. Business section of NVIDIA's business section:

• NVIDIA has invested over $58.2 billion in research and development since its inception.
• The company invented the GPU in 1999, which sparked the growth of the PC gaming market and redefined computer graphics.
• NVIDIA introduced the CUDA programming model in 2006, opening parallel processing capabilities to a broad range of compute-intensive applications.
• In 2012, the AlexNet neural network trained on NVIDIA GPUs won the ImageNet computer image recognition competition.
• The company introduced its first Tensor Core GPU in 2017 and its first autonomous driving system-on-chips (SoC) in 2018.
• NVIDIA acquired Mellanox in 2020, expanding its innovation canvas to include networking and enabling data center-scale platforms.

Item 1A. Risk Factors.summary:
Here are the key facts from the PART I - Item 1A. Risk Factors section of NVDA's Annual Report on Form 10-K in bullet points:

* Failure to meet the evolving needs of our industry and markets may adversely impact our financial results.
* Competition could adversely impact our market share and financial results.
* Long manufacturing lead times and uncertain supply and component availability can lead to mismatches between supply and demand.
* Dependency on third-party suppliers reduces our control over product quantity and quality, manufacturing yields, and product delivery schedules.
* Defects in products can cause significant expenses to remediate and damage the business.
* Adverse economic conditions may harm our business.
* International sales and operations expose us to risks that could harm our business.
* Product, system security, and data breaches/cyber-attacks can disrupt operations and affect financial condition, stock price, and reputation.
* Business disruptions can harm operations and financial results.
* Climate change may have a long-term impact on the business.
* A significant amount of revenue stems from a limited number of partners and distributors, making us vulnerable to loss or disruption.
* We may struggle to attract, retain, and motivate executives and key employees.
* Modification or interruption of business processes and information systems can disrupt operations.
* Operating results have fluctuated in the past and may fluctuate in the future, affecting stock price.
* Complex laws, rules, regulations, and political actions can impact our business.
* Increased scrutiny on corporate sustainability practices could result in financial, reputational, or operational harm and liability.
* Issues related to responsible use of technologies, including AI, may result in reputational or financial harm and liability.

Item 1C. Cybersecurity.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART I - Item 1C. Cybersecurity section in bullet points:

• The company has a risk management and strategy framework that follows processes outlined in the ISO 27001 international standard for Information Security.
• The company consults with external parties, such as cybersecurity firms and risk management and governance experts, on risk management and strategy.
• Identifying, assessing, and managing cybersecurity risk is integrated into the overall risk management systems and processes.
• The company has a vendor risk assessment process that evaluates cybersecurity risks associated with third-party suppliers.
• The company routinely assesses high-risk suppliers' conformance to industry standards such as ISO 27001, ISO 28001, and C-TPAT.
• Information security matters are overseen by the Company's Board of Directors, including the Audit Committee.
• The Audit Committee reviews the adequacy and effectiveness of the Company's information security policies and practices.
• A cross-functional leadership team meets regularly to review cybersecurity matters and evaluate emerging threats.
• The company has a Chief Security Officer with over 17 years of combined government and private sector assignments.

Item 2. Properties.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART I - Item 2. Properties section:

• Our headquarters is located in Santa Clara, California.
• We own and lease approximately 3 million square feet of office and building space for our corporate headquarters.
• We lease data center space in Santa Clara, California.
• We also own and lease facilities for data centers, research and development, sales and administrative purposes in various international locations.

Item 5. Market for Registrant's Common E.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART II - Item 5. Market for Registrant's Common Equity, Related Stockholder Matters and Issuer Purchases of Equity Securities section in bullet points:

• Our common stock is traded on the Nasdaq Global Select Market under the symbol NVDA.
• Public trading of our common stock began on January 22, 1999.
• As of February 21, 2025, we had approximately 842 registered shareholders.
• In May 2024, we announced a ten-for-one stock split, which was effected through an amendment to our Restated Certificate of Incorporation.
• The share split increased the number of shares of authorized common stock from 8.0 billion to 80.0 billion.
• On August 26, 2024, our Board of Directors approved an additional $50 billion to our share repurchase authorization.
• In fiscal year 2025, we repurchased 310 million shares of our common stock for $34.0 billion.
• As of January 26, 2025, we were authorized to repurchase up to $38.7 billion of our common stock.
• In fiscal year 2025, we paid cash dividends to our shareholders of $834 million.
• From January 27, 2025 through February 21, 2025, we repurchased 29 million shares for $3.7 billion pursuant to a pre-established trading plan.
• During fiscal year 2025, we withheld approximately 59 million shares for a total value of $6.9 billion through net share settlements.
• On December 6, 2024, we issued a total of 94,560 shares of our common stock valued at approximately $13.5 million to key employees.
• On December 29, 2024, we issued a total of 205,110 shares of our common stock valued at approximately $28.1 million to key employees.

Item 7. Management's Discussion and Anal.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART II - Item 7. Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations section, formatted as bullet points:

• Revenue growth in fiscal year 2025 was driven by data center compute and networking platforms for accelerated computing and AI solutions.
• Demand estimates for NVIDIA's products, applications, and services can be incorrect and create volatility in revenue or supply levels.
• The company began shipping production systems of the Blackwell architecture in the fourth quarter of fiscal year 2025.
• Increased demand for Data Center systems has driven increased purchase volumes with existing and new suppliers to support demand projections.
• NVIDIA has incurred and may incur inventory provisions or impairments if inventory or supply or capacity commitments exceed demand for products or demand declines.

Item 7A. Quantitative and Qualitative Di.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART II - Item 7A. Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk section:

• As of the end of fiscal year 2025, a parallel shift in the yield curve of plus or minus 0.5% would result in a change in fair value for NVDA's investment portfolio of $238 million.

• As of the end of fiscal year 2025, NVDA had $8.5 billion of senior Notes outstanding.

• The impact of foreign currency transaction gain or loss included in determining net income was not significant for fiscal years 2025 and 2024.

• If the U.S. dollar strengthened by 10% as of January 26, 2025, the amount recorded in accumulated other comprehensive income (loss) related to NVDA's foreign exchange contracts before tax effect would have been $136 million lower.

• An adverse 10% foreign exchange rate change applied to NVDA's balance sheet hedging contracts would have resulted in an adverse impact on income before taxes of $129 million as of January 26, 2025.

Item 9A. Controls and Procedures.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART II - Item 9A. Controls and Procedures section in bullet points:

• As of January 26, 2025, our management concluded that our disclosure controls and procedures were effective to provide reasonable assurance that information required to be disclosed in reports filed under the Exchange Act is recorded, processed, summarized, and reported within specified time periods.

• Our management established and maintained adequate internal control over financial reporting as of January 26, 2025, based on the criteria set forth in Internal Control - Integrated Framework (2013).

• The effectiveness of our internal control over financial reporting was audited by PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP, an independent registered public accounting firm.

• There have been no changes in our internal control over financial reporting during the quarter ended January 26, 2025 that have materially affected or are reasonably likely to affect it.

• Our management does not expect that our disclosure controls and procedures or internal controls will prevent all error or fraud, as a control system can provide only reasonable assurance.

Item 9B. Other Information.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART II - Item 9B. Other Information section in bullet points:

• A trading arrangement was adopted by the Board of Directors and/or officers on September 27, 2024.
• The trading arrangement is intended to satisfy the affirmative defense conditions of Rule 10b5-1(c).
• The plan for sales under the arrangement was set to run from September 27, 2024 to March 31, 2026.
• No shares were sold under the plan prior to its termination.

Item 10. Directors, Executive Officers a.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART III - Item 10. Directors, Executive Officers and Corporate Governance section:

• The identification of directors will be contained in the company's 2025 Proxy Statement under the caption "Proposal 1 — Election of Directors."
• The information regarding executive officers is available in Part I of this Annual Report on Form 10-K.
• Information about the Audit Committee and Financial Experts can be found in the company's 2025 Proxy Statement.
• Procedures for recommending directors are outlined in the company's 2025 Proxy Statement.
• The full text of the Code of Conduct and Financial Team Code of Conduct is published on the Investor Relations portion of the company's website at www.nvidia.com.
• Amendments to the Code of Conduct or waivers granted to executive officers or directors will be disclosed on the company's website or in a report on Form 8-K.

Item 12. Security Ownership of Certain B.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART III - Item 12. Security Ownership of Certain Beneficial Owners and Management and Related Stockholder Matters:

• NVIDIA's 2025 Proxy Statement will contain information regarding ownership of NVIDIA securities, including that of beneficial owners and management.
• The information about equity compensation plans required by this item will also be contained in NVIDIA's 2025 Proxy Statement under the caption "Equity Compensation Plan Information."

Item 15. Exhibits and Financial Statemen.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART IV - Item 15. Exhibits and Financial Statement Schedules section of NVIDIA Corporation's report:

• The auditor has audited the company's consolidated balance sheets as of January 26, 2025, and January 28, 2024, and related statements for each of the three years ended January 26, 2025.
• The auditor has also audited the company's internal control over financial reporting as of January 26, 2025.
• The consolidated financial statements present fairly, in all material respects, the company's financial position as of January 26, 2025 and January 28, 2024, and the results of its operations for each of the three years ended January 26, 2025.
• The auditor believes that their audits provide a reasonable basis for their opinions on the company's consolidated financial statements and internal control over financial reporting.
